issue.title: Make BIKE decode function void to avoid ct issues
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
The `decode` function in BIKE was made void to avoid any potential constant-time issues.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->
Partially addresses #1396 

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider), [OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl), [OQS-BoringSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl), and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body:
The latest commit removed the BIKE CT-error suppression without adding a curated one and in consequence now [constant time tests](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/1f62f66a4722e34cf82a69adbd953786d087b4f0/.github/workflows/weekly.yml#L15-L24) fail for all BIKE variants. 
@thomwiggers @dstebila : Are your approvals indicating your intention to scrap the `valgrind` testing then or have you given it without consideration of the (weekly run) tests by @jschanck ?

comment.body:
> the existing suppressions need to be reconstructed because a bunch of the code moved back from c files into .h files

Will you add this to this PR then or do you want to do a separate PR as soon as weekly CI constant time testing fails (maybe also a "solution" for #1400)?

issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
The `decode` function in BIKE was made void to avoid any potential constant-time issues.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->
Partially addresses #1396 

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider), [OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl), [OQS-BoringSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl), and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

comment.body:
> I have not run this code, but it looks decent. 

Well, removing suppression (as done here) means all (also false positive) `valgrind` findings are triggered and ct testing fails. As part of my review, I did run this code through "test_constant_time.py" to see whether it indeed is flawless as the PR implies by eliminating suppression entirely -- but it failed. See the documentation in https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/main/tests/test_constant_time.py.

> I was expecting such problems to be caught by CI though.

It is -- but only after the merge as we moved these very compute-intensive tests to weekly testing in an effort to have faster CI cycles and be more environmentally and economically sensitive: This decision possibly needs to be reverted as it  creates a false belief about this particular code property if the author does not run the test locally. The latter is necessary to check the `valgrind` report and do a suitable suppression file - manually checking & documenting each and every `valgrind` finding for correctness. Again, see the documentation in https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/main/tests/test_constant_time.py. Now also added a statement to the [Contributing Wiki](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/wiki/Contributing-guide#contributing-new-quantum-safe-algorithms).

issue.title: Implement full TLS1.3 OQS signature support
issue.body: Warning: This is a _big_ issue. Anyone willing to tackle it should consider this requires substantial OpenSSL3 support (see for example https://github.com/openssl/openssl/issues/10512). Also helpful to get started may be discussions [documented here](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/issues/243).

comment.body: Not running these tests on each push probably makes sense, but not automatically running them at all before pushing is indeed maybe also inconvenient and error-prone. I'm not sure if this can easily be set up in Github Actions or CircleCI, but it would be nice if it would be possible to run a second layer of CI tests "pre-merge". I think I've seen such stuff in the Rust project with e.g. their bot Bors (https://github.com/rust-lang/homu), which can also roll up a bunch of changes and subject them to the large test suite together. Checking if a commit is a "roll-up" should at least be easy.

issue.title: Make BIKE decode function void to avoid ct issues
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
The `decode` function in BIKE was made void to avoid any potential constant-time issues.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->
Partially addresses #1396 

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider), [OQS-OpenSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl), [OQS-BoringSSL](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/boringssl), and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body:
> The latest commit removed the BIKE CT-error suppression without adding a curated one and in consequence now [constant time tests](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/1f62f66a4722e34cf82a69adbd953786d087b4f0/.github/workflows/weekly.yml#L15-L24) fail for all BIKE variants. @thomwiggers @dstebila : Are your approvals indicating your intention to scrap the `valgrind` testing then or have you given it without consideration of the (weekly run) tests by @jschanck ?

No I hadn't given consideration of the constant-time feature, thanks for catching that, Michael.

@dkostic, is the current BIKE implementation intended to be constant-time?  If so, then there are potential non-constant-time lines that will need to be investigated, and either fixed or manually flagged as not a problem via suppression files.  If it's not intended to be constant-time, then the lines in the issues.json file need to be restored.

If you want to see what's being detected, here is how to do it.  

```bash
# use the OQS Docker CI image
docker pull openquantumsafe/ci-ubuntu-focal-x86_64:latest
docker run -dti openquantumsafe/ci-ubuntu-focal-x86_64:latest /bin/bash
docker attach <identifier output by previous command>
# clone your repo
git clone git@github.com:dkostic/liboqs
cd liboqs
git checkout bike-fix-ct-issues
# build with constant-time test enabled
cmake -GNinja -DOQS_OPT_TARGET=generic -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug -DOQS_ENABLE_TEST_CONSTANT_TIME=ON ..
ninja
# run Valgrind on BIKE-L1
valgrind --tool=memcheck --gen-suppressions=all --error-exitcode=1 --max-stackframe=20480000 --num-callers=20 tests/test_kem BIKE-L1
```
